[[Yamaha YZF-R1]] }} [[Image:2006Ducati999R-001.jpg|thumb|right|2006 Ducati 999R Xerox]] The '''Ducati 999''' is a [[Types of motorcycles#Sport bike|sport bike]] made by [[Ducati]] from 2003 to 2006. It superseded the [[Massimo Tamburini]] designed [[Ducati 916]], [[Ducati 996]] and [[Ducati 998]] range of superbikes. This motorcycle enjoyed great success in [[Superbike World Championship|World Superbike]], and was raced in the series through the 2007 season, despite no longer being produced, pending rules changes by the series' governing body, [[Fédération Internationale de Motocyclisme|FIM]], to allow competition of the new [[Ducati 1098]]. The 999 was designed by [[Pierre Terblanche]], amid much controversy over its styling. It is known as a high performance, race oriented motorcycle. With its traditional [[Ducati]] L Twin Desmodromic Valve actuated engine layout, it has a linear power delivery, with high power and torque figures available even at low RPM. Additionally, with its high spec suspension and trellis chassis, it is one of the finest handling motorcycles for its time. Subsequently, more powerful 999S and 999R versions were introduced, both capable of 0-62 mph (0-100 km/h) in under three seconds; and a top speed of over {{convert|170|mph|abbr=on|-1}}. The 2005 Ducati 999S won the Maxisport category for the prestigious international [[Masterbike|Masterbike 2005]] comparison and finished second overall. It has received critical acclaim from many corners, such as MCN of the U.K. which called it "simply the best V-Twin on the planet", and Motorbikestoday.com, which described it as "the most desirable, most exciting roadbike on the planet" in 2004. MotorcycleUSA.com described it as "stupendous" and "the epitome of V-Twin power." Also known as “the F1 of the motorcycles” in 2005. ==Racing== From the start the 999 was very successful in the [[Superbike World Championship]], winning world championships in: * 2003 [[Neil Hodgson]] * 2004 [[James Toseland]] * 2006 [[Troy Bayliss]] [[Gregorio Lavilla]] also won the [[2005_British_Superbike_Championship_season|2005 BSB Title]] on a 999 F04. ==Specifications== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! ! 999 (2003) ! 999 (2006) ! 999S (2006) ! 999R (2006) ! 999R Xerox (2006) |- ! {{short description|Standard motorcycle}} {{Infobox motorcycle | name = Indian FTR | image = File:Indian FTR 1200 - special.jpg | alt = | caption = | aka = | manufacturer = [[Polaris Inc.]] | parent_company = | production = 2019–present | assembly = | predecessor = | successor = | class = [[Standard motorcycle|Standard]] | engine = 1203 cc liquid-cooled, four-stroke 60-degree, 4-valve, [[v-twin]] | bore_stroke = {{cvt|102|×|73.6|mm}} | compression = 12.5:1 | top_speed = | power = {{convert|111|hp}} | torque = {{convert|80|lbft}} | ignition = | transmission = Slipper clutch, 6-speed [[Sequential manual transmission|sequential transmission]], chain-drive | frame = Steel [[trellis frame]] | suspension = Front: 43mm [[telescopic fork]]
Rear: Monoshock | brakes = Front: dual 320 mm [[Brembo]] | tires = 19 inch front, 18 inch rear | rake_trail = 26.3-degree rake, {{convert|5.1|inch}} trail | wheelbase = {{convert|60|inch}} | length = | width = | height = | seat_height = {{convert|33.6|inch}} | dry_weight = | wet_weight = {{convert|495|lb}} (unfueled) | fuel_capacity = {{convert|3.4|usgal}} | oil_capacity = | fuel_consumption = {{convert|32|mpgus}} | turning_radius = | range = {{convert|100|miles}} | related = | sp = | footnotes = Data from ''Cycle World'' }} The '''Indian FTR''' (formerly '''FTR 1200''') is a [[standard motorcycle]] manufactured by [[Polaris Inc.]] under the [[Indian Motorcycle Manufacturing Company|Indian Motorcycle marque]] since 2019. The FTR1200 and its derivative, the FTR1200S, have been noted as having design cues from the sport of flat track racing, including the airbox location, dual exhaust pipes, lightweight appearance, in contradistinction to the usual American [[cruiser motorcycle]], and "directly target[s] enthusiast riders who currently have traditionally favored the [[Ducati Monster]], [[Triumph Speed Triple]] and [[BMW R nineT]]". The "sport" model FTR1200S has [[electronic stability control]] and [[wheelie]] control, with gyroscopic input to the ABS and other systems to make them lean sensitive. ==FTR750== The [[Indian Scout FTR750]] [[Track racing#Flat track|flat track racing]] motorcycle is similar in appearance. ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{citation|title=2019 Indian FTR1200 First Ride Review|author=Mark Hoyer|date=May 6, 2019|work=[[Cycle World]]|url=https://www.cycleworld.com/2019-indian-ftr1200-first-ride-review/}} {{citation|title=INDIAN FTR1200 (2019-on) review|work=[[Motor Cycle News]]|date=May 6, 2019|url=https://www.motorcyclenews.com/bike-reviews/indian/ftr1200/2019/}} {{citation|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|title="Everyone Loves That Bike!" The Allure of the Indian FTR 1200 S Motorcycle|author=Hannah Elliott|date=September 17, 2019|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-17/indian-ftr-1200-s-motorcycle-review-everyone-loves-that-bike}} {{citation|work=[[Popular Science]]|title=Indian's FTR 1200 S motorcycle is everything a modern sport bike should be|author=Dan Carney|date=September 26, 2019|url=https://www.popsci.com/indian-ftr-1200-motorcycle-sport-bike-review/}} {{citation|publisher=[[CNet]]|title=The 2019 Indian FTR1200 is here, it's a hooligan bike and I need it|author=Kyle Hyatt|url=https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/2019-indian-ftr1200-flat-track-production-debut/}} }} ==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.indianmotorcycle.com/en-us/ftr1200/}} {{Motorcycle-stub}} [[Category:Indian Motorcycles|FTR1200]] [[Category:Motorcycles introduced in 2019]] [[Category:Standard motorcycles]] [[Category:Motorcycles of the United States]]

{{Short description|Czech motorcycle}} [[File:Jawa Motopark2011.jpg|thumb|Jawa 660 Sportard (red on the right) in the model range of Jawa in 2011]] The '''Jawa 660''' was a [[motorcycle]], produced by [[Jawa Moto]] in the [[Czech Republic]] in 2011-2018. The predecessor was the [[Jawa 650]]. The motorcycle is made in three versions: the Jawa 660 Sportard, Adenium and Vintage. The Adenium is slightly altered Sportard, main changes include in: 19" front wheel, crash bar, higher front plexiglass, main stand, rear diode light and side trunk carriers. The Vintage is a retro version, produced since 2017 in the design of [[Jawa 350|Jawa 350/634]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Jawa představila dva nové modely pro rok 2017|url=https://silnicnimotorky.cz/motorky/novinky/jawa-predstavila-dva-nove-modely-pro-rok-2017/|work=Silničnímotorky.cz|date=21 February 2017|language=cs-CZ}}</ref> Since 2014, it was imported through the ''F2 Motorcycles'' dealer also to the [[United Kingdom|UK]].<ref>{{cite news|title=JAWA 660 SPORTARD REVIEW|url=https://www.morebikes.co.uk/10619/jawa-660-sportard-review/|work=MoreBikes|date=19 September 2014}}</ref>
== Specifications == * Motor: [[Minarelli]] SOHC, water-cooled four-stroke single-cylinder with EFI injection ( same as [[Yamaha XT660Z Ténéré|Yamaha XT660Z Teneré]] ) * Displacement: 660 cm3 * Power: 36 kW @ 6000 ot./min * Max. torque: 58 Nm @ 5500 ot./min * Emission standards: Euro 3 * Frame: tubular steel * Wheelbase: 1497 mm * Transmission: five-speed * Wheels: front 17" 120(130)/70 or 19" 100/90, and rear 17" 150(180)/70(60) * Brakes: rear disc 220 mm, front 2x discs 305 mm * Dry weight: 189 kg * Tank capacity: 15 L * Max. speed: 170 km/h<ref>{{cite web|title=Jawa 660 Sportard/Adenium|url=http://www.motorkari.cz/motokatalog/jawa/jawa-660-sportard.html|website=Motorkari.cz|language=cs}}</ref> * Fuel consumption: 4.5 L/100 km * Acceleration 0–100 km/h: 5 s<ref>{{cite news|title=Jawa 660 Sportard: česká novinka v testu|url=http://www.zavolantem.cz/jawa-660-sportard-ceska-novinka-v-testu|work=Zavolantem.cz|date=1 March 2012|language=cs}}</ref>

{{convert|476.0|lb|abbr=on|order=flip}} (H2R) |fuel_capacity = {{convert|17.03|l|abbr=on}} }} [[File:Kawasaki Ninja H2R Seattle motorcycle show.jpg|thumb|Track-only Ninja H2R]] [[File:Kawasaki Ninja H2 SX - Mondial de l'Automobile de Paris 2018 - 002.jpg|thumb|Ninja H2 SX]] The '''Kawasaki Ninja H2''' is a "[[Supercharger|supercharged]] [[Super sport (motorcycle)|supersport]]"-class{{sfn|Shields|2014}} [[motorcycle]] in the [[Kawasaki Ninja|Ninja]] [[Sport bike|sports bike]] series manufactured by [[Kawasaki Heavy Industries Motorcycle & Engine|Kawasaki]], featuring a variable-speed [[centrifugal-type supercharger|centrifugal supercharger]].{{sfn|Newland|2014}}{{sfn|Bennetts|2014}}{{sfn|Olgiati|2014}}{{cite web|title=Video: Supercharged Kawasaki Ninja H2 on Engine Dyno|work=Sport Rider|date=September 24, 2014|url=http://www.sportrider.com/sportbike-news/video-supercharched-kawasaki-ninja-h2-engine-dyno|url-status=dead|archive-date=2014-09-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140927001504/http://www.sportrider.com/sportbike-news/video-supercharched-kawasaki-ninja-h2-engine-dyno}} Its namesake is the 750 cc [[Kawasaki H2 Mach IV]],{{sfn|Motor Cycle News|2014}}{{youTube|bkXRk5JvnrA|Ninja H2: Vol.6 promotional video}} published by Kawasaki, September 16, 2014 an [[straight-three engine|inline triple]] that was introduced by Kawasaki in 1972 to "disrupt what it saw as a sleeping motorcycle market".{{sfn|Cameron|2014a}} Its '''Ninja H2R''' track-only variant is the fastest and most powerful production motorcycle on the market, producing a maximum of {{convert|310|hp}} and {{convert|326|hp}} with [[Ram-air intake|ram-air]]. The H2R has 50% more power than the fastest [[Street-legal vehicle|street-legal]] motorcycles,{{Which|date=August 2022}} while the street-legal Ninja H2 has a lower power output of {{convert|200|hp|abbr=on}}{{cite web |title=Is this the New 2015 Kawasaki H2 street version teaser video? |url=http://www.sportrider.com/sportbike-news/new-2015-kawasaki-h2-street-version-teaser-video |work=Sport Rider |date=October 5, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-10-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007231640/http://www.sportrider.com/sportbike-news/new-2015-kawasaki-h2-street-version-teaser-video}}–{{convert|210|hp|abbr=on}} with ram-air. == Design == Kawasaki selected the [[literbike]] platform for its top-of-the-line Ninja H2 model, rather than continuing with the higher-displacement [[Kawasaki Ninja ZX-14|Ninja ZX-14]] [[hyperbike]]. ''[[Cycle World]]'''s [[Kevin Cameron (journalist)|Kevin Cameron]] explained that the literbike class is "the center of the high-performance market", attracting the best development in racing, with the best chassis and suspension design, so it made sense for Kawasaki to create a machine that could leverage this.{{sfn|Cameron|2014a}} The H2 is the first production motorcycle with a supercharger,{{sfn|Kunitsugu|2014}} although [[turbocharger]]s were available on [[Turbocharger#Motorcycles|some models]] in the early 1980s. Specifications in the infobox are from Kawasaki unless noted.{{citation |title=2015 Ninja H2 specifications |url=http://kawasaki.com/Products/2015-Ninja-H2 |publisher=Kawasaki |access-date=2014-11-05}} === Production === The [[street-legal vehicle|street-legal]] Ninja H2 has [[Side-view mirror|mirrors]] in place of the track-only H2R's winglets, and plastic body panels in place of the H2R's [[Carbon-fiber-reinforced polymers|carbon-fiber]] panels. The street-legal H2 is said to make {{convert|200|hp}}, probably with reduced supercharger boost compared to the H2R. The H2 and H2R share the supercharger (with a lower boost level on the H2) and many other components, with the exception of the [[head gasket]], cam profile and timing with ECU mapping, exhaust system, and clutch (the H2R's clutch has two additional plates). For 2017, Kawasaki made a limited-edition model with 120 units produced globally: the individually-numbered '''Kawasaki Ninja H2 Carbon''' with special paint and carbon-fiber upper cowl. For 2017, the standard Ninja H2 was also updated.{{cite web |date=February 2, 2017 |title=Kawasaki Unveils Limited Edition 2017 Ninja H2 Carbon Superbike |url=http://www.motorcyclistonline.com/kawasaki-unveils-limited-edition-2017-ninja-h2-carbon-superbike#page-2// |access-date=February 6, 2017 |publisher=[[Motorcyclist (magazine)|Motorcyclist]]}} For 2018, Kawasaki made a new [[sport touring]] version of the H2, the '''{{vanchor|Kawasaki H2 SX}}''', with a claimed wet weight of {{convert|564.5|lb|abbr=on|order=flip}}. Features that are options on the base model H2 SX come standard on the '''Kawasaki H2 SX SE''', which has a claimed wet weight of {{convert|573.3|lb|abbr=on|order=flip}}.{{cite web |last=Kunitsugu |first=Kent |date=March 28, 2018 |title=Kawasaki's 2018 H2 SX SE Is The Most Powerful Sport-Tourer You Can Buy |url=https://www.cycleworld.com/kawasakis-2018-h2-sx-se-is-most-powerful-sport-tourer-you-can-buy// |access-date=April 17, 2016 |magazine=[[Cycle World]]}} With revised throttle bodies, camshafts, crankshaft, pistons, cylinder and cylinder head as well as a new exhaust system aimed at increasing mid range torque. The intake system and supercharger impeller were also redesigned. A new larger fuel tank, rear trellis subframe and panniers increase the bike's weight by {{convert|19|lbs}}.{{cite web |last=Gustafson |first=Joseph |date=November 7, 2017 |title=2018 Kawasaki H2 SX Sport-Tourer Debuts—Get Ready To Wet Your Gore-Tex |url=https://www.cycleworld.com/2018-kawasaki-h2-sx-sport-tourer-debut// |access-date=November 14, 2016 |publisher=[[Cycle World]]}} For 2019, the H2 received an update with 15% more power from updates to the intake, spark plugs, ECU, and air filter, among other components. Also added was a new LED lighting scheme and a special top coat of paint that is claimed to be self-healing and able to smooth over small scratches in warmer conditions. Also new were lighter and smaller Brembo Stylema calipers, a new TFT dash, and smartphone connectivity that provides information about the GPS route, speed, RPM, current gear, fuel mileage, fuel level, and odometer.{{cite web |date=August 10, 2018 |title=Kawasaki Gives H2 Lineup More Power For 2019 |url=http://www.roadracingworld.com/news/kawasaki-gives-h2-lineup-more-power-for-2019// |access-date=August 14, 2018 |website=Roadracing World}}{{cite web |last=Chung |first=Dennis |date=August 10, 2018 |title=2019 Kawasaki Ninja H2 Updated, Now Claims 228HP |url=http://www.motorcycle.com/mini-features/2019-kawasaki-ninja-h2-updated-now-claims-228hp.html// |access-date=August 14, 2018 |website=Motorcycle.com}} In addition, the 2019 '''Ninja H2 SX SE+''' features electronically controlled suspension.{{Cite web |date=6 November 2018 |title=Kawasaki Upgrades 2019 Ninja H2 SX SE+ With Electronic Suspension And More |url=https://www.roadracingworld.com/news/kawasaki-upgrades-2019-ninja-h2-sx-se-with-electronic-suspension-and-more/ |access-date=2019-05-09 |website=www.roadracingworld.com}} === Engine and supercharger === The H2's engine is a {{Convert|998|cc|cuin|abbr=unit}} [[Multi-valve|4-valve]], [[DOHC|dual overhead cam]] [[Straight-four engine|inline-4]] with a two-speed [[Centrifugal-type supercharger|centrifugal]] [[supercharger]].{{sfn|Tibu|2014a}}{{sfn|Blain|2014}}{{sfn|Kiser|2014}}{{sfn|Cameron|2014b}} The supercharger is driven by a series of gears and shafts connecting the flywheel to a [[Epicyclic gearing|planetary drive]], finally spinning a [[Dog clutch|dog-shifted]] two-speed shaft attached to the [[impeller]].{{sfn|Cameron|2014b}} Throttle control is [[Electronic throttle control|electronic]].{{sfn|Cameron|2014c}} A centrifugal supercharger has the advantage of generating less heat than other designs, especially [[scroll-type supercharger|scroll-type]] or [[Screw type supercharger|screw-type]] superchargers.{{sfn|Cameron|2014b}}{{sfn|Kunitsugu|2014}} Without an [[intercooler]] (which the H2 lacks), excess heat in the intake charge can cause [[Engine knocking#Pre-ignition|pre-ignition]] that can damage or destroy the engine. === Electronic aids === Electronic rider aids include an [[anti-lock braking system]] (ABS), Kawasaki [[Traction control system|Traction Control]] (KTRC), Kawasaki [[Engine braking|Engine Brake]] Control (KEBC), a Kawasaki [[Quickshifter|Quick Shifter]] (KQS), an electronic [[steering damper]] (ESD), and Kawasaki [[Launch control (automotive)|Launch Control]] Mode (KLCM).{{sfn|Cameron|2014b}}{{sfn|Madson|2014}}{{Cite news|url=http://shifting-gears.com/kawasaki-ninja-h2-electronic-aids-revealed/|title=Kawasaki Ninja H2: Electronic aids revealed - Shifting-Gears|date=2014-10-20|work=Shifting-Gears|access-date=2017-09-27|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://speedsociety.com/kawasaki-ninja-h2-launch-control-and-quickshifter/|title=Kawasaki Ninja H2 Launch Control And Quickshifter|work=Speed Society|access-date=2017-09-27|language=en-US}} === Aerodynamics === {{Update|part=section|date=August 2022|reason=The description of the H2R's aero is hypothetical}} The front fairing of the Ninja H2R incorporates winglets{{sfn|Stock|2014}} made of [[carbon fiber]], just like the rest of the H2R-exclusive bodywork. They may be [[Automotive aerodynamics|aerodynamic devices]] designed to create a low-pressure zone to help move [[air cooling|cooling air]] through the engine bay,{{sfn|Lavrinc|2014}} to produce [[downforce]] at high speed,{{sfn|Kiser|2014}}{{sfn|Blain|2014}} or to provide [[Bicycle and motorcycle dynamics#Stability|straight-line stability]] in a short-[[wheelbase]] sportsbike chassis.{{sfn|Kunitsugu|2014}}{{sfn|Beeler|2014}} === Chassis === The H2 and H2R have a tubular, thin-wall steel [[trellis frame]] and a [[single-sided swingarm]],{{sfn|Kunitsugu|2014}} with a traditional sportsbike wheelbase of {{Convert|1450|mm|in|abbr=unit}}.{{sfn|Abrahams|2014}} Explaining the advantages of Kawasaki's approach to exploiting aerodynamics instead of lengthening the wheelbase, a South African writer{{Who|date=August 2022}} said, "It's easy to build stability into a hard-accelerating drag machine with a long wheelbase... but Kawasaki wanted a track-day machine, one that would also go round corners."{{sfn|Abrahams|2014}} High speed motorcycles often have long wheelbases. Extra length is added by the extended swingarm on a typical [[Motorcycle drag racing|drag motorcycle]], and a typical [[motorcycle land-speed record|land speed record]] [[streamliner]] has a meters-long wheelbase (3.7 meters for the current record holder, [[Ack Attack]]). == Pre-Intermot engine announcements and analysis == The H2 was announced by Kawasaki in a late-2014 [[teaser campaign]], and was widely expected to be fully revealed at the [[Intermot]] motorcycle trade show the same year. Before full details were released by Kawasaki, the supercharged inline-4 engine was thought by several industry observers to be identical to, or closely related to, a nearly 1,000 cc inline-4 with a centrifugal supercharger displayed by Kawasaki at the 2013 [[Tokyo Motor Show]].{{sfn|Bennetts|2014}}{{efn|Cameron also recalled Kawasaki's supercharged piston engine experience with the WWII era [[Kawasaki Ha40]] aircraft engine.{{sfn|Cameron|2014a}}}}{{sfn|Visordown|2014}} Cameron published an analysis showing that an engine of that displacement, mildly boosted at {{convert|5|psi|abbr=on}}, would generate {{convert|203|hp}}—more than that of Kawasaki's current leader, the {{convert|191.7|hp|adj=on}}{{cite web |last=Lenatsch |first=Nick |date=March 7, 2012 |url=http://www.cycleworld.com/2012/03/07/kawasaki-zx-14r-road-test// |title=Kawasaki ZX-14R – Road Test |work=[[Cycle World]] |access-date=July 4, 2016}} [[Kawasaki Ninja ZX-14|ZX-14]] (horsepower figures are expressed at the rear wheel). The same engine would generate {{convert|257|hp}} with {{convert|10|psi|abbr=on}} of pressure. His analysis included a discussion of the benefits of a [[Supercharger#Two-speed and two-stage superchargers|two-speed supercharger]] for more linear power delivery (as opposed to the intractable [[Forced induction in motorcycles#Forced induction in production motorcycles|Japanese turbo bikes of the 1980s]] that suffered from [[turbo lag]]). Cameron also said Kawasaki patent documents suggested the engine would rely on [[Evaporative cooler|evaporative cooling]] using port fuel injection, instead of a bulky [[intercooler]].{{sfn|Cameron|2014a}} Kawasaki claimed the 2013 model had the first supercharger designed by a motorcycle manufacturer.{{sfn|Ets-Hokin|2013}} In 2013, journalists said that the engine could power the "next generation [Ninja] ZX-14R" sportbike.{{sfn|Siler|2013}} Journalists also noted that Kawasaki already has a production inline-4 supercharged (albeit intercooled{{citation|title=2012 Jet Ski Ultra 300X detail & features |publisher=Kawasaki |date=c. 2014 |url=http://www.kawasaki.com/products/product-details-features.aspx?id=560&scid=0 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20140915184613/http://www.kawasaki.com/products/product-details-features.aspx?id=560&scid=0 |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-09-15 }}) engine powering the [[Jet Ski]] Ultra 300X [[personal watercraft]].{{cite web|title=Teaser video announces 2015 Kawasaki Ninja H2|date=September 1, 2014|work=Sport Rider |url=http://www.sportrider.com/sportbike-news/kawasaki-announces-2015-ninja-h2-teaser-video|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904192928/http://www.sportrider.com/sportbike-news/kawasaki-announces-2015-ninja-h2-teaser-video|archive-date=2014-09-04}}{{clear}} == Production announcement == [[File:Kawasaki motorcycle supercharged engine 2013 Tokyo Motor Show.jpg|thumb|left|Engine shown at 2013 [[Tokyo Motor Show]]; supercharger has cover embossed "Kawasaki" to right of cylinders]] [[File:Kawasaki Ninja H2R engine cutaway supercharger.JPG|thumb|Cutaway H2R engine and supercharger. Orange painted plenum surrounds impeller, behind which is visible part of planetary gear system.|left]] At the 2014 Intermot motorcycle trade show on September 30, 2014, Kawasaki announced that a race-only Ninja H2R model would be produced in addition to the detuned street-legal Ninja H2, which would be fully revealed at the [[EICMA]] trade show in November.{{sfn|Kiser|2014}}{{sfn|Motor Cycle News|2014}} The bike was shown for the first time in North America at the AIMExpo show at Orlando, Florida in October, 2014.{{sfn|Bornhop|2014}} According to details Kawasaki made public about the H2's engine at Intermot, it was confirmed to be a 998 cc [[inline-four engine]] with a supercharger, producing {{convert|300|hp}} in the track-only H2R variant, still by far the highest rated engine ever for any factory production motorcycle{{sfn|Kiser|2014}}{{sfn|Tibu|2014a}}{{sfn|Blain|2014}} (50% more than its nearest competitor, the [[BMW S1000RR]]).{{sfn|Motor Cycle News|2014}} === Reception === Global press coverage both before and after Intermot was extensive. Before the full reveal of the H2R, reactions tended to emphasize the reintroduction of [[Forced induction in motorcycles|forced induction to the motorcycle marketplace]], with headlines like "Hail the New Supercharged Era" ([[Autoevolution]]),{{sfn|Tibu|2014a}} "Supercharged Ninja imminent" (''[[Motor Cycle News]]''),{{sfn|Newland|2014}} "New Kawasaki sports bike will use a 1000cc supercharged engine" (Visordown (UK)),{{ref|Visordown|2014}} "Kawasaki officially uncovers Ninja H2 supercharger" (''Cycle Online'' (Australia)),{{sfn|Shields|2014}} "Kawasaki Ninja H2: How the supercharger works" (''[[:it:Motociclismo (rivista)|Motociclismo]]''),{{sfn|Olgiati|2014}} and "Kawasaki's H2 superbike: A technical look at Kawasaki’s upcoming supercharged superbike" (''Cycle World'').{{sfn|Cameron|2014a}} After the introduction, before any test rides had even been permitted, coverage turned to both the bike's unusual styling and its precedent setting power. Both industry and general-readership press said the machine "will beat up the supersport scene with a [[steam hammer]]" (''[[Der Tagesspiegel]]''),{{sfn|Walter|2014}} "smashes the superbike class" (Gizmag),{{sfn|Blain|2014}} is "a game changer" (Autoevolution),{{sfn|Tibu|2014b}} "a quantum leap into the future that redefines the way we see motorcycles" (Independent Newspapers),{{sfn|Abrahams|2014}} and "the poster child of 2-wheeled insanity ... so extreme it's hard to comprehend" (''[[Road & Track]]''),{{sfn|Kierstein|2014}} or was simply "radical" (''Motor Cycle News''){{sfn|Motor Cycle News|2014}} and even "ludicrous" (''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'').{{sfn|Stock|2014}} ''Cycle World'' and ''Motor Cycle News'' both commented on how Kawasaki had claimed the high end of the market with the H2, moving past a stagnant market (at least from the [[Japanese Big Four]] manufacturers) full of cookie-cutter sportsbikes and low-priced entry-level bikes, and had set up the H2 as a [[halo model]] for the entire brand. Cameron said, "When we look at the current crop of 1000s, all date from before our present "recession," and what little has come by way of new product has sought to please the mostly imaginary "new buyer" with low-tech delights."{{sfn|Cameron|2014b}} Highlighting Kawasaki's ability to create a product leveraging aerodynamic, turbine and engine technology design expertise from across the large [[Kawasaki Heavy Industries]] conglomerate (called a "vast industrial complex" by ''Sport Rider''{{sfn|Kunitsugu|2014}}), an unsigned ''Motor Cycle News'' piece said "The H2R you see here is the very pinnacle of what Kawasaki can do ... This is the firm's halo product, and every element is Kawasaki at its very best, from the engine and aerodynamic development, through to the mirror-finish black chrome paint specially developed for this model."{{sfn|Motor Cycle News|2014}} Some analysts noted odd features of the supposedly track-only H2R model. Although it is outfitted with [[racing slicks]] and lacks many features required on a [[street-legal vehicle]] in most jurisdictions, such as headlights, rear view mirrors, and turn signals visible from the front or sides, it also has features that are unusual or absent on pure track bikes, such as an ignition lock and LED tail light.{{sfn|Motor Cycle News|2014}}{{sfn|Beeler|2014}}{{clear}} == Speed record attempts == === H2 === ''[[Cycle World]]'' recorded a {{sfrac|1|4}}-mile time of 9.62 sec. @ {{Convert|152.01|mph|abbr=on}} with a 0 to 60 mph acceleration at 2.6 seconds and a top speed of {{Convert|183|mph|abbr=on}}. Kent Kunitsugu, editor for Sport Rider magazine, competing in a land-speed racing event in Mojave, California at the Mojave Air and Space Port airfield in the Mojave Magnum land-speed racing, took a Ninja H2 with just a few bolt-on performance parts adding over 70 horsepower and achieved a top speed of {{Convert|226.9|mph|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |last=Kunitsugu |first=Kent |date=July 7, 2016 |title=Video: High Speed – Running Kawasaki's Ninja H2 to 226.9 mph |url=http://www.sportrider.com/video-high-speed-running-kawasakis-ninja-h2-to-2269-mph// |access-date=July 21, 2016 |publisher=Sport Rider}}{{cite web |date=April 28, 2016 |title=Rotobox Carbon-Fiber Motorcycle Wheels Proven at 226.9 mph |url=http://www.sportrider.com/rotobox-carbon-fiber-motorcycle-wheels-proven-at-2269-mph// |access-date=July 21, 2016 |publisher=Sport Rider}}{{dead link|date=August 2022}} On August 12, 2018, rider Shigeru Yamashita, with an unofficial team of Kawasaki employees (known as Team 38),{{citation |title=Team 38 head to the Mojave Mile with the H2R |date=August 10, 2015 |url=https://www.kawasaki.co.uk/en/news/Team_38_head_to_the_Mojave_Mile_with_the_H2R_?Uid=0898DlgOC1FQCV8LWg1ZXAlRWwlQWA0LWVlcX1xQUV1fDFk |website=kawasaki.co.uk |access-date=January 1, 2019}} set a {{convert|202.743|mph|2|abbr=on}} speed record in the [[Southern California Timing Association]] (SCTA) P-PB 1000 class for under-1,000 cc displacement production supercharged motorcycles with limited modifications at the [[Bonneville Speedway]]. On August 15, Yamashita broke his own record with a new speed of {{convert|209.442|mph|2|abbr=on}}.{{citation |author=Abhilasha Singh |title=Kawasaki Ninja H2 to attempt land speed record at Bonneville Speed Week |date=August 12, 2018 |work=[[The Financial Express (India)|The Financial Express]]}}{{citation |title=Speed Week 2018 certified records |date=August 18, 2018 |url=http://nebula.wsimg.com/d2692d88c68116e5c45fd97f205b230a?AccessKeyId=1B489604A3781742F233&disposition=0&alloworigin=1 |page=8 |publisher=[[Southern California Timing Association]]}} === H2R === ==== 2015 ==== [[File:Kawasaki H2R in Isle of Man cropped.jpg|thumb|James Hillier's H2R (by Quattro Plant/Bournemouth Kawasaki).{{cite AV media |url=https://www.kawasaki.co.uk/en/news/A_lap_of_the_Isle_of_Man_TT_with_James_Hillier_-_aboard_the_H2R?Uid=08B7ClkOWlxQX1ELWF1YXAkLDFAJWAxeWloMXAxdUQ5YDFk |title=A lap of the Isle of Man TT with James Hillier - aboard the H2R |date=21 August 2015 |publisher=Kawasaki UK |access-date=12 January 2019}} at [[TT Grandstand|race paddock]] during TT week in 2015 [[Motorcycle tyre#Types|Tyre warmers]] were electrically heated before the demonstration run.[https://www.iomtt.com/news/2015/06/11/hillier-hits-highest-speed-on-h2r Hiilier hits highest speed on H2R - video] iomtt.com, 11 June 2015. Retrieved 12 January 2019]]In June 2015, [[Isle of Man TT|TT race]] competitor James Hillier rode a Kawasaki H2R around the 37{{frac|3|4}}-mile [[Isle of Man TT Mountain Course|TT road course]] as an inter-race demonstration lap at near-race speeds, using normal Superbike [[Racing slick|slick race tires]], leading to a TT record of the highest top speed attained in the [[Isle of Man]] by a motorcycle.{{cite web |date=June 11, 2015 |title=IOMTT: Hillier & Ninja H2R Set Roads TT Record (Video) |url=http://www.cycleworld.com/2015/06/11/iomtt-hillier-ninja-h2r-set-roads-tt-record// |access-date=November 21, 2016 |publisher=[[Cycle World]]}} The top speed of "over 206 mph" (332 km/h) on the [[Sulby, Isle of Man|Sulby Straight]] was recorded on Hillier's personal [[Strava]] [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] smartphone [[mobile app|app]] for cyclists.[http://www.iomtt.com/News/2015/June/11/Hillier-hits-highest-speed-on-H2R.aspx Hillier hits highest speed on H2R] IoM TT.com Official site Retrieved July 20, 2016 ==== 2016 ==== On June 30, 2016, [[Kenan Sofuoğlu|Kenan Sofuoglu]], a five-time world champion [[Supersport World Championship|Supersport]] circuit-racer, made a top speed attempt.{{cite web |last=Contractor |first=Sameer |date=July 1, 2016 |title=Kenan Sofuoglu Hits Top Speed of 400 Kmph on the Kawasaki Ninja H2R |url=http://auto.ndtv.com/news/kenan-sofuoglu-hits-top-speed-of-400-kmph-on-the-kawasaki-ninja-h2r-1426766// |access-date=July 1, 2016 |publisher=Car and Bike}}[http://www.worldsbk.com/en/champion/SSP WSBK official website.] Retrieved November 21, 2016 Kawasaki supplied a stock H2R augmented only with special tires developed by [[Pirelli]] for the top speed attempt to withstand extreme high speeds, and the bike was supplied with race-grade fuel.{{cite web |last=Tibu |first=Florin |date=July 1, 2016 |title=400 KM/H in 26 Seconds Aboard a Kawasaki Ninja H2R |url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/400-km-h-in-26-seconds-aboard-a-kawasaki-ninja-h2r-109019.html |access-date=July 1, 2016 |publisher=Autoevolution}} Sofuoglu was also supplied with a special one-piece leather suit to enhance aerodynamics for his record attempt. This attempt, with the Turkish president in attendance, was made across the then-newly completed [[Osman Gazi Bridge]], the fourth longest in the world at just over a mile and a half.{{cite web |date=July 1, 2016 |title=Kenan Sofuoglu hits a bonkers top speed of 400 kmph on the Kawasaki Ninja H2R |url=https://www.wheelstreet.in/blog/kenan-sofuoglu-land-speed-record-of-400-kmph-kawsaki-ninja-h2r/// |access-date=July 1, 2016 |publisher=WheelStreet}} Kawasaki quoted the H2R's maximum speed to be {{convert|380|km/h}}.{{cite web |last=Zoltan |first=Bogdan |date=July 1, 2016 |title=Kawasaki Ninja H2R Goes From 0 To 400KM/H Or 249MPH In 26 Seconds |url=http://www.carscoops.com/2016/07/kawasaki-ninja-h2r-goes-from-0-to.html |access-date=July 1, 2016 |publisher=Carscoops}} After training and preparing for four months, a speed of {{convert|400|km/h}} in just 26 seconds was claimed by a video-recording of the bike's dashboard display.{{cite web |last=MacDonald |first=Sean |date=July 7, 2016 |title=400 KPH On A Production Motorcycle |url=http://www.cycleworld.com/400-kph-on-production-motorcycle// |access-date=July 21, 2016 |publisher=[[Cycle World]]}}{{cite web |last=Sofuoglu |first=Kenan |date=June 30, 2016 |title=Kenan Sofuoglu break World record by reaching 400 kmh with Kawasaki Ninja H2R. HD |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cKBLkUIoauo// |access-date=June 30, 2016 |website=[[YouTube]]}}{{cite web |last=Azmi |first=Thoriq |date=July 1, 2016 |title=Kawasaki Ninja H2R hits 400km/h |url=http://www.bikesrepublic.com/bulletin/kawasaki-ninja-h2r-hits-400kmh// |access-date=July 1, 2016 |publisher=bikesRepublic.com}}{{cite web |last=Marsden |first=Liam |date=July 1, 2016 |title=Kenan Sofuoglu reaches 249mph on Kawasaki H2R |url=http://www.motorcyclenews.com/news/2016/july/kenan-sofuoglu-reaches-249mph-on-kawasaki-h2r/// |access-date=November 24, 2016 |publisher=[[Motor Cycle News]]}} The speed was not officially confirmed or independently verified. No fixed point optical sensors for distance/speed calculations, chronometers or hand-held devices were used,{{cite web |date=June 30, 2016 |title=Production Bike World Record 0-400 kmh in 26 sec. HD |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6_n7ru1e-rg// |access-date=June 30, 2016 |website=[[YouTube]]}} and later with a theoretical calculation,{{cite web |last=Collins |first=Andrew |date=June 30, 2016 |title=Kawasaki H2R Proves It Really Can Go 249 MPH On A (Closed) Public Road |url=http://lanesplitter.jalopnik.com/kawasaki-h2r-proves-it-really-can-go-250-mph-on-a-clos-1782923821// |access-date=July 1, 2016 |publisher=[[Jalopnik]]}} of the distance he traveled in 26 seconds on the {{convert|8,799|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}} bridge. Cameron had calculated two years earlier that with the right gearing, the H2R's engine power could theoretically overcome [[aerodynamic drag]] up to {{convert|250|-|260|mph}}.{{sfn|Cameron|2014b}}{{clear}} == See also == *[[Kawasaki Ninja]] series *[[List of fastest production motorcycles by acceleration]] == Footnotes == {{notelist}} === Notes revision.text:
{{Short description|Parallel twin motorcycle}} {{Infobox Motorcycle |name = MZ 1000S |image = [[File:MZ1000S-6.JPG|frameless|upright=1.35]] |caption= |aka = |manufacturer = [[MZ Motorrad- und Zweiradwerk|MZ Motorrad]] |parent_company = |production = 2004–2007 |predecessor = |successor = |class = [[Sport bike]]
[[Sport touring motorcycle|Sport-touring]] |engine = {{convert|998|cc|cid|abbr=on}} [[straight-twin engine|parallel twin]]{{cite web |url=http://www.motorcyclistonline.com/2005-mz-1000-review//|title=2005 MZ 1000 Review| publisher=[[Motorcyclist (magazine)|Motorcyclist]]|accessdate=January 27, 2017|date=March 19, 2013 }} |bore_stroke = {{Convert|96|×|69|mm|abbr=on}} |compression = 12.5:1 |top_speed = {{Convert|140|mph|abbr=on}} |power = {{convert|87|kW|hp|abbr=on}} at 9000 RPM{{cite web |url=http://www.topspeed.com/motorcycles/motorcycle-reviews/mz/2006-mz-1000s-ar14696.html//|last=Kodack |first=Anthony |title=2006 MZ 1000S| publisher=Top Speed|accessdate=January 27, 2017|date=October 19, 2006 }} |torque = {{Convert|72|lbft|abbr=on}} |ignition = |transmission =wet multi-plate hydraulic clutch
6-speed cassette gearbox
chain final drive R/H side |frame = Chrome-moly tubular steel
Twin-beam |suspension = Front: 43 mm Marzocchi inverted telescopic forks, fully adjustable
Rear: Alloy cantilever swingarm, Sachs shock, fully adjustable |brakes = Front: 2 x 320 mm disc, 4-piston caliper
Rear: 240 mm disc, 2-piston caliper |tires = Front: 120/70-17
Rear: 180/55-17 |rake_trail = 24.5°, {{Convert|98|mm|abbr=on}} |wheelbase = {{convert|56.1|in|abbr=on}} |length = |width = |height = |seat_height = {{convert|32.3|in|abbr=on|order=flip}} |dry_weight = |wet_weight = {{convert|513|lb|abbr=on}} |fuel_capacity = {{convert|5.2|gal|abbr=on|order=flip}} |oil_capacity = |fuel_consumption = {{convert|40|mpgus|abbr=on|order=flip}} |turning_radius = |related = }} '''MZ 1000S''' is a 998 cc 180-degree [[straight-twin engine|parallel twin]] [[motorcycle]] produced between 2004 and 2007 released in the USA in 2005 by the now defunct German company [[MZ Motorrad- und Zweiradwerk|MZ Motorrad]]. Once the flagship of the range, the 1000S was MZ's largest-ever displacement motorcycle, and their first multi-cylinder bike since 1959. The MZ 1000S was the most powerful production inline twin cylinder engine worldwide. == Company history == In the Communist era, the East German firm MZ Motorrad produced only single-cylinder, small-displacement motorcycles. These were mostly rugged 2-stroke commuters, from which MZ developed successful 250 cc [[ISDT]] machines. MZ were then world leaders in 2-stroke design, but chief engineer and rider [[Ernst Degner]] defected to the West, selling MZ technical know-how to [[Suzuki]]. Degner's defection [http://www.motorcycleclassics.com/classic-japanese-motorcycles/suzuki-ernst-degner-ze0z1202zsch] After the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, MZ had access to Western designers and resources, and they hoped to move into a more sophisticated market. In 1994 the factory produced the [[MZ Skorpion|Skorpion]] range. Conceived by British design firm Seymour Powell, it used a 660 cc Yamaha single-cylinder engine. The Skorpion was followed in 2001 by the Baghira [[motard]], which also used the Yamaha engine. Later, after being taken over by [[Hong Leong Group]] of Malaysia, MZ began a project to produce its own 1000cc superbike, but MZ stopped all production in 2013. == Development history == The 1000S "New Edge" design was drawn by Peter Naumann who designed the [[F-117 Stealth Fighter]], and the 1000S won a silver medal from International Design Forum. Initial reports were that this would have a V-twin engine, but MZ eventually opted for a parallel-twin instead with a 180° crank. Motorcycle News October 2002 The frame is a twin-spar design, not unlike that of the [[Aprilia SL1000 Falco|Aprilia Falco]]; but whereas the Falco has an alloy frame, the MZ used chrome-moly steel. The prototype model of the 1000S was previewed during [[Intermot]] 2000 in Germany and went into production in 2003. The bike initially sold well, particularly in Germany. MZ, who had grand plans to become a major world manufacturer, went on to produce some variants of the 1000S such as the MZ 1000SF naked bike and MZ 1000ST sports touring bike. Financial troubles set in and the MZ factory was closed. ==Model range== ===MZ 1000S=== Although the '''S''' model is a [[sport bike]] with [[clip-ons]] and rear-set footrests, the bike is nevertheless comfortable and capable of touring with a pillion passenger. Its engine is a [[Radiator|liquid-cooled]] 999 cc [[DOHC]] 8-valve [[4-stroke]] 40° inclined parallel twin with a 180° crankshaft, and a balance shaft.{{Vague|date=June 2015}}MZ 1000S Spares Catalogue It has electronic [[fuel injection]], and [[Wet sump|wet-sump]] lubrication. It has [[Nissin Kogyo|Nissin]] brakes, [[Marzocchi]] male-slider forks, and an alloy [[cantilever]] [[swinging arm|swingarm]] rear suspension. Although the engine is compact, the bike is fairly heavy at 208 kg (dry). ===MZ 1000ST=== The '''ST''' is a milder [[sport touring|sports-tourer]] motorcycle based on the "S". The engine is detuned for more torque but still produces {{convert|83|kW|hp|abbr=on}}. Compared to the "S", the ST is modified for touring comfort, with higher handlebars and lower footrests to provide a roomier seating position for long distance riding. The screen is 30 mm higher for better wind protection. A plusher rear seat provides more comfort for the pillion. The ST's engine has altered clutch springs to reduce the effort required to operate the clutch. {{ill|Krauser GmbH|de|Krauser (Unternehmen)|lt=Krauser}} hard luggage may be fitted, and a steering damper keeps the bike stable when fully loaded. [[File:MZ 1000SF right front view.JPG|upright|thumb|MZ 1000SF]] [[File:MZ 1000 S und SF.jpg|thumb|S & SF bikes together]] === MZ 1000SF === The '''SF''' "SuperFighter" is a naked [[streetfighter]], using the same engine as the ST.{{cite web |url=http://www.visordown.com/reviews/motorcycles/naked/mz-1000sf//|title=MZ 1000SF review | publisher=Visor Down|accessdate=January 27, 2017|date=January 1, 2006 }} ==Reception== The MZ 1000 was quite well received, although [[Motorcycle News|MCN]] journalists thought it rather expensive and "poor value". MCN damned the bike with faint praise, saying: "But as the [[Yamaha TRX850]] demonstrated, many bikers aren't especially keen on parallel twins..." and "MZ is trying something different with its parallel twin 1000S and Streetfighter, but it lacks the X factor and doesn't have the kind of dealer/distributor back-up you need when buying a slightly oddball motorbike." However, in a four-bike comparison test in 2005 between the [[Honda VTR1000F|Honda Firestorm]], [[Ducati SuperSport|Ducati 1000SS]], [[Suzuki SV1000]], ''Fast Bikes'' magazine declared the MZ 1000S the clear winner, saying: "It combines the uniqueness and style of the Italian, with the usability and build quality of the Japanese, and to top it all off is far more fun to ride than any of them."''Fast Bikes'' January 2005 page 57 [[Motorcyclist (magazine)|Motorcyclist]] praised the bike saying: "The MZ 1000 is a well-engineered, capable machine that is built to last..." ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.motorcycle-usa.com/2005/01/article/2005-mz-1000s///|last=Bruder |first=Grosser |title=2005 MZ 1000S| publisher=Motorcycle USA|accessdate=January 28, 2017|date=January 28, 2005 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.motorcyclenews.com/bike-reviews/mz/1000s/2004///|title=MZ 1000S (2004-2007) Review| publisher=[[Motorcycle News]]|accessdate=January 27, 2017|date=November 23, 2006 }} }} ==External links== * [http://www.muz.de MZ Motorrad Germany] * [http://www.visordown.com/reviews/motorcycles/sports-tourers/mz-1000s-2004---2007/review/4132.html Visordown review] * [http://www.motorcyclenews.com/bike-reviews/mz/1000s/2004/ Motorcycle News review] * [http://www.motorbikestoday.com/reviews/Articles/mz_1000s.htm Motorbikes Today review] * [http://www.motorcycle-usa.com/16/361/Motorcycle-Article/2004-MZ-1000S.aspx Motorcycle USA review 2004] * [http://www.motorcycle-usa.com/18/847/Motorcycle-Article/2005-MZ-1000S.aspx Motorcycle USA review 2005] [[Category:MZ motorcycles|1]] [[Category:Motorcycles introduced in 2004]] [[Category:Sport bikes]] [[Category:Sport touring motorcycles]] [[Category:Motorcycles powered by straight-twin engines]]

{{Infobox Motorcycle |name = Yamaha WR250F |image =File:2002WR250F.jpg |aka = |manufacturer = [[Yamaha Motor Company]] |parent_company = |production = |model_year = 2001 - present |predecessor = |successor = |class = [[types of motorcycles#Off-road|Off road]], [[Enduro motorcycle|Enduro]] |engine = {{convert|246|cc|cuin|abbr=on}} [[Single-cylinder]]; [[four-stroke]], [[Radiator (engine cooling)|liquid-cooled]], [[DOHC]], [[Multivalve|5 titanium valves]] |bore_stroke = {{Convert|77.0|x|53.6|mm|abbr=on}} |compression = 12.5:1 |ignition = [[Capacitor discharge ignition|CDI]] |top_speed = |torque = |power = |transmission = Constant-mesh 6-speed; multiplate wet clutch, chain drive |suspension = Front: Inverted telescopic fork; fully adjustable, {{Convert|11.8|in|abbr=on}} travel
Rear: single shock; fully adjustable, {{Convert|12.2|in|abbr=on}} travel |brakes = Front: hydraulic single disc brake, 250 mm
Rear: hydraulic single disc brake, 245 mm |tires = Front: 80/100-21 51M
Rear: 100/100-18-59M |rake_trail = |wheelbase = {{Convert|58.3|in|abbr=on}} |length = {{Convert|85.2|in|abbr=on}} |width = {{Convert|32.5|in|abbr=on}} |height = {{Convert|51.1|in|abbr=on}} |seat_height = {{Convert|38.6 |in|abbr=on}} |dry_weight = |wet_weight = {{Convert|256|lb|abbr=on}} (claimed){{Official|http://www.yamaha-motor.com/sport/products/modelspecs/66/0/specs.aspx}} |fuel_capacity = {{Convert|2.1|usgal|abbr=on}} |oil_capacity = |fuel_consumption = {{Convert|71|mpgus|abbr=on}}{{cn|date=March 2011}} |turning_radius = |climbing_ability = |related = [[Yamaha YZ250F]] [[Yamaha WR450F]] [[Yamaha WR250R]] }} The '''Yamaha WR250F''' is an [[types of motorcycles#Off-road|off-road]] motorcycle made by [[Yamaha Motor Company]]. It has a {{Convert|250|cc|abbr=on}} [[Radiator (engine cooling)|liquid-cooled]] [[single-cylinder|single]] [[nikasil]] coated [[cylinder (engine)|cylinder]] engine. First offered in 2001, it shared many components and design concepts with the [[Yamaha YZ250F|YZ250F]] motocross model. It is basically the YZ250F detuned slightly for more controllable power, with a headlight and lighting coil, softer suspension, a [[kickstand]], better noise specifications, larger radiators, and lower emissions. The WR250F is basically a YZ250F modified for enduro competitions, extreme enduro competitions and hard enduro competitions and the practice of these extreme sports. http://www.totalmotorcycle.com/photos/2008models/2008models-Yamaha-WR250F.htm Total motorcycle.com 2008 Yamaha WR250F The WR in the name indicates a [[Gear ratio#Wide-ratio vs. close-ratio transmission|wide-ratio gear box]] common to most [[Enduro motorcycle|enduro]] or trail bikes and stands in contrast to the close-ratio gearbox essential to a [[motocross]] racer. Over the years the WR250F has benefited from the advances made in the YZ motocross version gaining advancements such as an aluminum frame and improved suspension. Despite the similar name, it shares very few common components with the heavier, street-legal dual sport dirt oriented [[Yamaha WR250R|WR250R]] or its sister supermoto build WR250X. ==Significant advances== {| class="wikitable" |- | 2003 || Automatic decompression exhaust cam and electric starting |- | 2006 || Digital display |- | 2007|| Aluminium frame |- | 2015|| Bilateral beam frame, 6-speed transmission, Rear slant cylinder, KYB SSS Forks, and Fuel Injection{{cite web |last1=Dension |first1=Chris |last2=Booth |first2=Adam |title=First Impression: 2015 Yamaha WR250F |url=https://www.dirtrider.com/features/2015-yamaha-wr250f-first-impression#page-4 |website=Dirt Rider |access-date=7 May 2019 |date=12 December 2014}} |} == See also == * [[Yamaha WR250R]] * [[Yamaha WR450F]] * [[Yamaha YZ250F]] == References == {{commonscat|Yamaha WR}} {{Reflist|30em}} {{Yamaha motorcycles}} {{Yamaha motorcycles timeline}} [[Category:Yamaha motorcycles|WR250R]] [[Category:Off-road motorcycles]] [[Category:Motorcycles introduced in 2001]]

{{Hatnote|For other Honda Motorcycles with CBX prefix, see [[Honda CBX (disambiguation)]]}} {{Infobox motorcycle |name = Honda CBX550F |image = Honda CBX550 cropped.jpg |image_size = |aka = CBX550 Four |manufacturer = [[Honda|Honda Motor Company]] |parent_company = |production = 1982–1986 |assembly = |predecessor = |successor = |class = [[Types of motorcycles#Sport touring|Sport touring]] |engine = {{convert|572.5|cc|abbr=on}} [[Four stroke]] [[Multi-cylinder engine#Four-cylinder engines|in-line four]] |bore_stroke = {{convert|59.2|x|52.0|mm|abbr=on}} |compression = 9.5:1 |top_speed = |power = |torque = |ignition = Transistorised |transmission = 6-[[Gear train|speed]] [[Manual transmission|manual]], [[Roller chain|chain]] final drive |frame = [[Motorcycle frame|Duplex cradle; tubular steel]] |suspension = [[Motorcycle fork#Telescopic|Telescopic]] with air assistance front: cantilever with air assistance, rear{{cite book|last=Shoemark|first=Pete|title=Honda CBX550 572.5cc 1982 to 1986: Owners Workshop Manual|date=1989|publisher=Haynes|page=90|ISBN=0856969400}} |brakes = Front: [[Disc brakes|Twin hydraulic disc]]
Rear: single hydraulic disc |tires = 3.60H18-4PR, front: 4.10H18-4PR, rear |rake_trail = |wheelbase = {{convert|1.380|m|abbr=on}} |length = {{convert|2.085|m|abbr=on}} |width = {{convert|0.740|m|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|1.080|m|abbr=on}} (F)
{{convert|1.270|m|abbr=on}} (F II) |seat_height = {{convert|0.785|m|abbr=on}} |dry_weight = {{convert|184|kg|abbr=on}} (F)
{{convert|190|kg|abbr=on}} (F II) |wet_weight = |fuel_capacity = {{convert|17.0|l|abbr=on}} |oil_capacity = {{convert|3.0|l|abbr=on}} |fuel_consumption = |turning_radius = |related = [[Honda CBX1000]]
[[Honda CBX750]]
[[Honda CBX650]]
[[Honda CBX400F]]
[[Honda CBX series#CBX 250|Honda CBX250]] |sp = uk }} The '''Honda CBX550F''' is a [[Four-stroke engine|four-stroke]], [[Multi-cylinder engine#Four-cylinder engines|in line four cylinder]], [[Types of motorcycles#Sport touring|sport tourer]] motorcycle produced from 1982 to 1986 by the [[Honda|Honda Motor Company]].{{cite book|last=Shoemark|first=Pete|title=Honda CBX550 572.5cc 1982 to 1986: Owners Workshop Manual|date=1989|publisher=Haynes|ISBN=0856969400}} The CBX550F II is identical apart from the addition of a [[Motorcycle fairing#Half fairing|half-fairing]].{{cite book|last=Shoemark|first=Pete|title=Honda CBX550 572.5cc 1982 to 1986: Owners Workshop Manual|date=1989|publisher=Haynes|page=6|ISBN=0856969400}} Although the model was designated ''550'', the actual capacity was {{convert|572.5|cc|abbr=on}}. Honda developed a completely new, unusual design of engine to compete in the middleweight-sector with twin [[overhead camshaft]]s acting on [[Rocker arm|rockers]], having screw-adjusters for [[Four-stroke engine#Valve clearance|clearance]] which actuated the sixteen valves ([[Multi-valve|four per cylinder]]). The engine featured a standard [[Oil cooling|oil-cooler]] and a distinctive, unusual exhaust system, a first for Honda, with cross-over pipes directly in front of the engine linking cylinders one to four and a separate pair of pipes connecting cylinders two and three. The CV carburettors were of a new type using [[Carburetor#Choke|mixture-enriching]] internal fuel passages for cold-starts, with careful engineering of the inlet tracts to achieve smooth gasflow.''[[Motor Cycle News]]'' (UK weekly newspaper) 5 May 1982, p.21 ''Honda CBX550.This gem sets new standards'', Terry Snelling. Accessed and added 2015-11-02 The machine was noted for its use of inboard ventilated [[disc brakes]], the discs themselves being contained within a "drum" type enclosure. Front suspension was by oil-damped [[Motorcycle fork#telescopic|telescopic fork]] with air assistance and incorporating an anti-dive mechanism in the left fork leg. Rear suspension was by Honda's own "Pro-Link" rising rate system, which allows the suspension forces to vary in accordance with rear wheel movement. The machine was equipped with transistorised ignition and electrics were 12 volt. ==See also== *[[Honda CBX series]] *[[Honda CBX (disambiguation)]] ==References== ;Footnotes {{reflist}} ;Sources Where not already otherwise noted, specifications obtained from, {{cite book|last=Shoemark|first=Pete|title=Honda CBX550 572.5cc 1982 to 1986: Owners Workshop Manual|date=1989|publisher=Haynes|ISBN=0856969400}} {{Honda_motorcycles_(1980s)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:HondaCbx550}} [[Category:Honda motorcycles|CBX550F]] [[Category:Motorcycles introduced in 1982]] [[Category:Sport touring motorcycles]]
